reviewText:
Early Access Review

A familiar game yet completely unique
I have over 7,000 hours of Dota2 played. I invested a fair amount of time in Heroes of Newerth before that and Heroes of the Storm since. And while this game is probably not an ARTS/MOBA, it has a lot of the elements that drew me to the genre.

Despite being turn based the game never feels slow. All players share the same 20 seconds to decide what they want to do for that turn, which keeps the pacing sharp and rewards quick decision making. It is long enough to remove the 'twitch reflexes' aspect from other games, which is a bonus for me as I'm approaching gamer's old age.

The controls are simple and the mechanics are intuitive. As long as you understand that each phase (Prep, Dash, Blast, Move) is simultaneous within itself it's pretty easy to grasp why a dead freelancer is still able to get off that monster full-team ultimate.

But like the simplicity of chess, it's just a framework to outplay your opponents. The game is only as easy as the enemy team makes it. That 6-hp Lockwood is definitely going to dash and stay alive, right? So your entire team covers places he can jump to and secure the kill. But he just stands there and shoots you all for massive damage. Mind games and bluffing are front and center in Atlas Reactor and to me that's the core of a competitive game.


tl;dr
Pros
-Crisp pacing within a turn based context
-Simple controls and intuitive mechanics
-Complex gameplay that heavily features mind games
-Very friendly community (for now, best to assume this will diminish as the game grows)
-Reflexes are irrelevant, but quick decision making is key
-As far from p2w as you can possibly get

Cons
-Unoptimized in beta (This will undoubtably change as the game moves towards release but I would be remiss to not mention it)

-Plays much better with voice chat, which requires a third-party client like the official Discord server found here[discord.gg]

-Game is very much geared toward 4-stacks. Solo queue can be extremely chaotic, so unless you use the Discord server to find people or just collect players as you go the experience can be pretty hit-or-miss.

In light of this, my in game tag is mal3diction#5080. If anyone wants to try out the game and wants some company, I'd love to hang out with new players and help shield you from YOLO queue!

Early Access Review

It's a simultaneous turn-based multiplayer arena game, and it isn't easy.

I think that's kind of it - the learning curve is pretty steep, and there's no way around it. Knowing when to dash, guessing when enemies are going to do the same, what abilities fire when, and juggling all of that in 30 or so seconds... It isn't easy.

But is it fun?

Hells to the yes. There's so much deep strategy there, and when everyone's acting in concert it's a beautiful thing. It feels a lot like a MOBA in that sense - each character can do a short list of things, and it's everyone's job to make sure the team is greater than the sum of its parts.

It's in Early Access for a reason, tho - they do need to work on some polish, and need ways to communicate ideas clearly without typing (because seriously, that time limit? It makes you think FAST), but the game itself reeeeeeeally scratches that frantic strategy itch.

Go buy it. Go play it.

An honest review of Atlas Reactor.
__________________________

*As a heads up, I do not have the game installed on through Steam, I have it installed through Glyph. I played the game since it was in its Pre-Alpha stages of development and have continued played since.*

** PLEASE KEEP IN MIND THAT ATLAS REACTOR IS STILL IN EARLY ACCESS/BETA DEVELOPMENT, THERE ARE FEATURES WHICH STILL NEED TO BE ADDED TO THE AND/OR FINE TUNED. ATLAS REACTOR IS NOT A FINSHED PRODUCT YET! **

Atlas Reactor, an easy to pick up and understand group turn-based MOBA with an interesting and deep depth of strategy to the game.
__________________________

Atlas Reactor is an interesting take on the MOBA genre, it plays likes a turn-base strategy game while also having the competiveness of similar MOBAs like League of Legends and DOTA 2.  In Atlas Reactor, you control a single character called a Freelancer with in a team of 3 other Freelancers. Each Freelancer have their own unique abilities and ways of playing. The goal of is to beat your enemy teem through one of these win condition; first team to 5 kills (Kills are points on the scoreboard) wins or the team with the most kills by the end of turn 20 wins. A game in Atlas Reactor will only last for 20 turns unless the score is tied by turn 20, if that happens than the game goes into an overtime/sudden death. The first team to break the tie score wins. While in Overtime/Sudden Death, a game can go on past turn 20 (I have had matches which have lasted till turn 30+ before).

Atlas Reactor plays at a very timely pace for all players, but that doesn’t necessarily mean all players play at the same pace. For some players, the games pacing may be to slow for them or way to fast when they first start playing the game. Matches tend to be played in a similar way that chess is played, you are meant to analyze what your opponent is doing to figure out your best way to outsmart them while your opponent does the same thing to you, the biggest difference is that you only control 1 piece which can perform multiple action in the game and you must cooperate with 3 other players (this can be rather rough to do since not everyone is going to think the same way, but that is the of a competitive MOBA). Because of this, the game will likely be harder for some players to pick up and understand than compared to others who have a “knack” for games like this.

Though Atlas Reactor is turn-base, combat is done simultaneously based on the phase of combat. This means all Prep abilities activate during the prep phase, all Dash abilities activate in the dash phase, all blast abilities activate in the blast phase, and all movement is done at the end of the blast phase.
___________________________

Pros and Cons of Atlas Reactor

+Pros+
+ Unique Freelancers
+ Good Win Conditions
+ Simple to pick up with deep strategy
+ Fairly easy gameplay with a small introductory learning curve.
+ All Freelancers are free forever!
+ The only Payed unlockables are purely cosmetic, no Pay2Win advantages.
+ Able to unlock unique cosmetic content and some purchasable content through crafting in steading of paying for    it

-Cons-
- The game may be more difficult for some players to understand
- The game has glitches are problems within matches and UI (the game is in EA/Beta still)
- Match fluidity varies between slow and fast (matters on how players play the game)
- Some in game information may be hard to pick up on (Ability Telegraphs)
- Match experience in dependent on how players play and how team comps are made (a bad experience while playing Atlas Reactor may be cause of people pick characters that they just want to try without knowing how to play them).
- The games learning curve will very based on a players experience with MOBAs and Turn-Based strategy games.
___________________________

Here is a quick rundown on why this game is a game you are paying for now and not using the F2P model. Atlas Reactor was originally meant to be a Free 2 Play game, its consumer model with originally designed with that in mind and a lot of the games Alpha/Beta players played the game in its F2P model, but there was an issue with it, the game ended up being rather frustrating to play and develop because you needed really grind a lot of hours to unlock a freelancer(s), a lot of the games development was being used to balance and manage a micro transaction method that was surrounded by people purchasing Freelancers. It clashed with a lot of the games fun dynamics because it would stop players from experiencing the game that other who had all the Freelancers unlocked would experience, this also would cause a problem for upcoming features such as Ranked mode. So, in order to fix this problem, the Atlas Reactor development team decided to go from a F2P model to a buy once and play for ever model in order to keep players on even footing and so everyone is capable of having a good experience in the game overall.

I'll admit, I first got this after the Overwatch open beta ended, and I was craving more of the same. At first glance it might seem similar if you ignore ALL the information about the game. Fortunately, it was an entirely different game, and has become one of my absolute favorite surprises in a long time.

This is a turn based tactics competitive strategy game. First to five kills, 4v4, but you can make custom games which change up that formula. This a purely PVP game, with no PVE aspect (unless you play with bots). You move on a grid and on each turn you have twenty seconds to decide what to do. Within that time frame, you can see your team mate's moves but not the enemies. After the twenty seconds, all turns play simultaneously in a specific order of operations. It ends up playing like a very animated game of chess. Your whole team may plan to attack one person, but before the attack phase is the dash phase, and if that enemy dashes all your teams attacks will still play out, each one missing the shot. Which could place them in a bad spot, or maybe another enemy accidentally dashes into someones line of fire and gets killed.

The strategy of the game is not the abilities or perfectly placed shots, but correctly guessing your opponents next move or two. This is not a twitch game, which is refreshing. I'm not against twitch games. I've played those my entire life and they are my favorite genre. But this is a nice change of pace. Seeing your team mate's choreographed moves executed as planned and out-smarting the entire team is one of the best experiences I've had in a competitive game in a long time.

I cannot get enough of this game even in this state and I sincerely hope it does well once it comes out.  It needs more players. No pay to win. Microtransactions are only for cosmetics and taunts. Free updates and characters for everyone. This scratches an itch I never knew existed.

I've been playing since Alpha Sneak Peak, so my Steam time is inaccurate. (My Steam key was given to me by Trion, but that's because I already owned Atlas Reactor.)

Atlas Reactor takes the turn-based gameplay of XCOM and throws it into a team arena, and tops it all off with a colorful, cyberpunk world.

If you like strategy games, you'll probably like this. Although it does still require you to be quick-thinking with time limits, but even post-surgery I was able to play without stressing (I didn't do well, but that's to be expected on all those meds).

As its still beta/early access, there's only 3 maps and 16 characters, only one game mode and no ranked play yet, but the gameplay is so solid that I'm loving it in spite of the option limitations.

Each character has their strengths and are all distinct from each other, with customization on secondary features on their abilities to make them play the way you want - and no one combination seems to be the best for anyone. There's no real team composition meta, either- sure, 1 frontliner, 2 firepower, and a support might seem optimal, but I've won games as and lost games to things like 3 frontliners + 1 support, or 3 supports + 1 firepower. So every match is going to play out uniquely.

There's also no RNG to get angry over. Abilities do fixed damage, moves happen in certain phases, all there is is your skill and ability to predict what the other team is doing, and communicate with your team on what to do.

tl;dr: Are you looking for a great strategic turn-based experience? Buy this game.
Not looking for that? This might not be your speed.
Should you give this game a try if you have the option to? Absolutely.

As a player that has been playing this game since its Open Alpha I feel I can say that Atlas Reactor is a very unique turn-based MOBA that really sets itself apart from any other games in the MOBA genre. If you don't like turn-based combat then you should probably resume browsing for other games on Steam as this is not the game for you. With it's unique cast of characters a new player will be able to find someone that fits their playstyle. Healer (Support), Tank (Frontline), DPS (Firepower) this game has it all. From a happy-go-lucky ball of nuclear energy to a Cold Blooded shotgun totting killer, this game covers a whole spectrum of personalities that add to the fun.

The gameplay at it's core consists of 4 phases: Decision, Prep, Dash, and Blast. In this order in game it allows for many situations full of outplays that will seperate the skilled from the average. This makes the game fun as you can watch yourself grown and you can learn a lot from one match if you're paying attention. The gameplay never feels repetitive as every game allows for different team combinations and different decisions to change the experience.

The only problems right now is the small playerbase and the fact that queueing solo is not the best way to have a great experience. The queue times can be a bit long depending on the time you choose to play because of the smaller playerbase, but even then they aren't that long. I've never had a queue longer than 5 minutes. Queuing as a 4 man is easily the most enjoyable way to play this game which is a shame, but it's expected. Friends always make games better. Now if you don't have anyone in specific to play with you can join this  Discord [discordapp.com] and find people in the community to play with!

The game is definitely worth a try and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a turn-based experience.

This game is fantastic, but it is not for everyone. The gameplay is a hero-based, 4 vs 4, turn-based combat. Everyone inputs their moves, having 20 seconds to do so. Then, all the actions resolve simultaneously, according to a clearly defined priority list. So it is possible to dodge an attack that you know is coming, but if your opponent predicts your dodge, he can attack instead the new location you are moving to.  The maps are well made, the champ design is great, and the game has good art, music, and sound. Game balance is constantly evolving but is currently in a good place, where almost all characters are viable.

The unique feature about the turn based combat is that it is fully deterministic. There is no random chance for crit or miss, or random effects on skills, so the outcome of a battle fully depends on your ability to outplay your opponent.

There are three main ways of doing that: You can keep information hidden from your opponent by utilizing fog of war, predicting the moves your opponents will do and reacting to them, and making moves that are not predicted by your opponent. For example, if you know that all your opponents expect you to dodge to safety, they might not even attack you. What better time to stand still and unleash your strongest skill?

I've played over 100 hours of atlas reactor and the game is still very fresh. It's more fun playing in a group, so bring your friends or check out the free discord server and have fun!

Atlas Reactor is a 4v4 arena deathmatch with a goal to kill 5 enemies before they do the same to you. (So yes, there is respawning.) Each character has a unique basic attack, 3 other moves typically with a multi-turn cooldown, 1 ultimate the fills up from using your moves, and then 3 non-character-specific one time use moves. Each turn you will use 1 ability and 1 move (or 2 moves). The other players will be making their moves simultaneously and everyone has 20 seconds each turnt o do so. Games are typically under 10 minutes.

OK, so how well does this work? Pretty well. There are some UI improvements to be made, but all in all the pacing is excellent. Skillful play is rewarded. Like MOBAs, knowledge of the game and characters is extremely important. You can also somewhat customize the skills of your character which can help solidfy your strategy in a premade group. The characters are fairly unique and people will certainly get attached to particular 'freelancers'. There are only 18 characters right now so the roster needs to grow before launch. But the gameplay is more than solid. It's refreshing, it's unique, and it's well done.

The biggest concern is the size of the playerbase. Right now queue times are fine, but $30 will be a steep price to pay when this game launches. I think this is worth $30 since the characters are all included (like Overwatch). However, it looks too much like a F2P game from the outside. And it's a unique concept which can sometimes find trouble taking hold. I think this game would do much better with a $20 price tag (like Rocket League). But I digress. The game is currently free for the weekend and while queue times are fine now, it's not exactly overflowing with players.

So do I recommend this game? Yes. You should play it. It's a fun game that blends XCOM and MOBAs into a unique package with a couple twists. Is it worth $30? Well, that's always going to be subjective. But for me, the answer is yes as long as the population is there.

Now onto the long review.  I figured I'd TL;DR first since people hate reading a ton of stuff.  I an ex-Quake pro, Street Fighter FGC member, and have been competitive in any game I liked that I could (Legend in Hearthstone, diamond in Starcraft II, plat in LoL).  This game fits right in there with the legends of competitive gaming, easy to learn, tough to master.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played during alpha, beta, and even live. Fun and addicting gameplay
Atlas Reactor is a turned based game unlike any of it's kind from before.

I've probably logged well over 50+ hours from alpha/beta alone, sadly it doesn't show on Steam :(

It looks to use concepts from other successful games such as league of legends (Champion system with 3 normal abilities and an ultimate) with a tile system like Final Fantasy Tactics (tiles on the ground but with different gameplay elements.) Each of these tiles can have various powerups as well (Extra Damage, HP regen, or Increased travel distance) The game lasts a set amount of turns, OR until one team has killed the enemy 5 times. So let's break it down into the four types of abilities the game offers.

Turn 1
Just briefly here, it's not really a phase. It applies to everyone. This is solely a movement phase. You choose on the map where you want to move, all other abilities are greyed out for this turn.

Turn 2 and beyond
This is where things get interesting. Every character is offered numerous abilities with various powerups/mods you can apply to them. There are FOUR different phases/types of abilities the game employs in a specific order:

Prep Phase
The prep phases occurs before any other action takes place. For example, some characters place mines on the ground or launch a nuke into the sky that will show where it is going to land. These prep phases occur before anything else happens and usually will activate at the start of the next turn with a few exceptions, but anybody can see them take place.

Dash Phase
I like to call it the dash phase. This is where you make dem crazy jukes. You're in somebodies line of sight, barely any hp left? Well you can use your dash ability (lets you move BEFORE the attack phase. Read below) and you can dodge the attack causing them to waste their turn, sometimes dash abilities can even cause damage to really let you gain the upperhand. You can also use this strategically to block predictable incoming enemy attacks for your allies.

Attack Phase
Where ♥♥♥♥ goes down. Literally. Everyone uses your attack here, but it's always planned out before hand. So if you choose to use an attack on somebody, but they've qued in a dash already it's going to miss. That's how the game works. BUT... If you predict where their dash is going to go... You can REALLY screw them over. This is where the complexity of the game comes in, and seeing how dashs also have huge cooldowns, counting turns is also a great idea.

Movement Phase
Finally the movement phase, at the end of the turn you can move your character. Remember in prep phase that tactical nuke we sent out? Well if you place it correctly, you can screw them over by having them walk into it at the end of this turn.

In a nutshell the game goes Prep>Dash>Attack>Movement ALWAYS in that order.

Feel like I've been rambling for awhile, so I'll sum up the game in a tl;dr with some pros and cons

Pros:
-Multiplayer so you can play with friends
-User friendly and easy learning curve, but for higher tiers of play expect to start counting cooldowns, planning attacks out carefully, and knowing what other characters do
-Interesting selection of characters - Theres a champion for everyone whether it's a tanky champ, support, or dps.
-Very good voice overs
-Not pay to win. You get a free champaion rotation, and every champion is purchasable via a Ingame currency" you get after every match similar to league.
-Bot matches for people that don't like PvP
-Good art - fun looking maps

Cons
-Online - some games you will have an ally disconnect
-Some characters might feel OP. I don't consider this really a con since once you learn
date: it's actually quite balanced.\n-Not very many maps
recommended: but already confirmed via their live stream more will be released\n-Smallish champion pool
hoursPlayed:
but more are coming

Final Thoughts:

This game is hella fun. It's really addictive and I've enjoyed it a lot. I can't think of anything thats horribly wrong with the game besides the obvious facts of playing a game online. Give it a shot and you won't regret it at all!

Final Rating: 9.5/10"

The first thing I can say is that the game uses a simple concept, and has very interesting details.
The real reason I really enjoyed playing this game is that the execution is spot on when it comes to all little things.

The main mechanic of the game consists of combat phases. This RPG style mechanic allows players to plan one (or more) actions to be executed during the turn and a move. The sequence of execution is particularly clear (Prep , Dash, Blast and Move). This simple mechanic allows for a lot of depth in the gameplay as it introduces the notion of outplay.
Prediction is as important as your actions in this game, which is what makes it an interesting game (and the execution is spot on, allowing for serious outplay and bluffs).

Tldr: With unacceptable business practices and already shadey price structure. This game seems to be another Trion cash grab. Except unlike the other ones, this isn't even good.

This review is not going to mention gameplay, whilst I have thoughts on it, I could not stomach enough hours to have a complete viewpoint.

Atlas Reactor is another game made by the infamous Trion, if you are unaware of this company stop and read to reviews for Trove (another game they made). This company seems to not care about the consumers, and only sell to people who haven't heard of Trion’s terrible practices.

However the main beef with this game lies in the technical and graphical aspects of the game. This game has absolutely terrible performance, which is odd, because Trove was an incredibly solid game tech wise. With an Evga FTW 750Ti I was unable to hit passable frame rates, being one of two games to have that be the case. Also loading screens were at times longer than Fallout 4 (Not a game to be compared to when loading times are involved). Even weirder, I frequently encountered various small and big gripes on the technical side of things, something Trove and Rift did not have. The first weird quirk I dealt with was the game opening two instances, a weird but forgivable issue. The next was the fact the game launched in laptop resolution windowed, non maximized and uncentered, more than ok if this issue didn't happen every time i launched the game. The third was crashes with no explanation, just a windows game encountered an error message. In fairness, Trove did have this last one, but only on OpenGL (and was even fixed).

However the most egregious problem on the technical side is the options menu. Never before have I seen such an abysmal set of options. The first issue with it is the fact there’s only 2 audio sliders, sound and voice oddly absent even when they should be in the game. Also you have to drag from the slider point, no click to go to where you want. The graphics are just low, medium, high, full screen mode, and resolution. For a game with this level of complexity, this is unacceptable, more so when this company should know better (Trove had a pretty solid set of options). Even more of a problem, there are no tooltips, thus I am unable to tell what the options even do.

However let us say the technical problems are fixed (which I doubt), this still leaves another problem as well; graphics and art style. This game follows the cell shaded style of games like Borderlands 2 and some cartoon elements like TF2, however the style ends up looking sloppy and unpolished. The art almost looks like someone picked it solely because it can excuse the poor graphics (which it can’t), and is what's considered the new trend in the market. Which brings me to my next point, this game just looks like it's trying to hop on every trend and see what sticks. Sci fi cartoon cell shaded colorful hero based skin-fest game with abilities, sounds like a mouthful but sums up this new trend, and this game ticks all the boxes, It feels like it's trying to fit with this trend, because that's what people want now.

This still leaves graphics, this game looks like it would fit right in graphics fidelity wise with Borderlands 2, a game that came out in 2012. The graphics are dated, with old looking menus and antique animation. However the real problem (and the one that made me stop playing) is the heavy handed use of blue. It’s everywhere, the menus, the grid, highlights for attacks, the allies info, it’s all blue. If this game allowed me to change colors (hint hint) I wouldn't care, just a quick menu change. However we are stuck with this, and it makes the game harder than it should. Players may not be able to tell what's part of the map, where the grid is, or where attacks go when it all starts heating up. It starts to get pretty crazy and with not enough tooltips or color changes, it makes it crazy when it doesn't need to. This isn't going to be a problem with people who have played the game enough (and isn't as much of a problem to people who play games like this). The thing is, this is a problem that shouldn't exist, someone, somewhere should have stopped and thought “Maybe it shouldn't ALL be blue”. This also makes the game more confusing to watch, especially if you lose track of the easy to blend in cursor.

All in all, gameplay aside, I just couldn't get into the game. With a heaping of problems one after the other my patience wore out, if you are a casual video game player, avoid. If you are willing to slog through the problems to maybe understand the potentially good game, be my guest. However I think I shouldn't have to do so, and as such, won't.

Edit: Some have said Glyph (the launcher for this game) is spyware, I have no clue if this is true, but thought people should be aware that's a thing.

Early Access Review

Early Access Watcher Reviews Atlas Reactor

Update Version: Initial EA release

Disclosure: This game copy was played during the free weekend promotional event

If one thing can be certain in any industry it is how people are destined to either copy or create adaptations of successful products. This is certainly true in the gaming sphere where a successful new genre IP will eventually be mimicked to ad nauseam. Some happen over night (FNAF clones) while others, in the case of the MOBA genre, have taken years to mimic the addictive Warcraft III custom map Defense of the Ancients (which also had clones to ad nauseam.) This time around, we have a MOBA wrapped in a couple layers of turn based sheets with Atlas Reactor. Is this attempt to deviate from the standard three lane, mob fest the shot in the arm the genre needed or simply a failed experiment? Regardless of what it is, I will commend it for trying something different.

When I first saw this game, I was quite pleased with the aesthetic. The humor they tried to attach to it does not hold up, but the simple designs stand out thanks to the bright color schemes. Characters are diverse from your standard humans to robots and some bizarre aliens. Particle effects and lighting are not as up to par, but the character animations look fluid from movement to ultimate attacks. It does not have a lot of moving parts, but it is easy on the eyes.

This game took a giant risk utilizing turn based elements and it will be a deal breaker for a lot of players. You have four phases that all characters act out even if killed: prep for traps, dash for emergency movement, battle for attacks and then movement. Each character plays out there actions even if they are killed and can even be healed as long as the health recovered is more than the damage received. This is where the majority of the challenge settles; anticipating where a enemy will move, where they will attack and who they decide to gang up on. A simple dash phase can be the difference between a well executed team effort or a narrow escape to disrupt a perfect kill. The problem is with the waiting that is involved after selecting the round action. You need to watch every move until everyone has gone, which can make anyone impatient. If someone is killed, they must wait a full turn (the turn after they are killed) before they can respawn on the map in a random location. The first team to kill five or have the most kills at 20 rounds (or most in overtime) will be deemed the winner. If you play strategically though, you will find it can be a ripe challenge to get even three kills by the 20 round mark.

Micro-transactions are forgivable for a free to play game that is fully released, but if I paid $20 to access the game and then discovered lot of it is in the store, I would be rather disappointed. This is not so much B2P as it is B2A (buy to access). The content on offer is rather slim too with just a handful of maps and around 20 characters, which thankfully have skills you can swap out (after unlocked) to change up the gameplay style a little. As it stands now though, there is not enough on offer to qualify the price tag.

This game is an online title, so the game is only worth it if you can play it. There have been several times I have played only to have my entire team drop out at once with half the enemy team doing the same. Online queues felt rather long, even with the free weekend. I decided to talk with some players outside of the game client to see if this was normal before it came to Early Access and was told that was the case. It just arrived on Early Access recently, but a game with this small a community can make finding matches a pain.

The options menu left much to be desired with only the broad option to set low, medium or high quality and decide if you want full screen or windowed. Volume options, profanity filter and chat options exist, but there really is nothing to incorporate Antialiasing or V-Sync. It could explain why the graphics appear slightly bland on appearance. Frame rate drops occurred from time to time as well, mostly during dash phases when multiple characters were sprinting at the same time. Loading screen freezes also happened to activate while loading into the game using the client, which required a forced shut down of the program. It could certainly be worse, I will give the developers that.

It is always a positive step for developers to try new things, but it doesn't mean the attempt will be received well. The game has an interesting and challenging approach to a genre over saturated to death with routine and meta builds that eliminate the fun required for a game to be great. That said, a game also needs to be worth the price of admission and at this point the game just isn't worth the $20 entry fee. You are also forced to use a third party service that was more trouble using than removing thanks to my anti-virus (not using Avast) labeling it as a threat. It has a great idea to work off of, but it is ultimately a non-recommendation due to technical issues and cost. I will eventually try this game again in the future, so hopefully then it will be ironed out and have a larger community.

Pros

- Visually pleasant to look at
- Challenging tactical gameplay
- Tutorial, Solo and Co-op with bots (plenty of options to learn instead of throwing in blind to the wolves)
- Varies skills and abilities to unlock to allow characters different play styles

Cons

- Micro-Transactions (You paid at least $20 dollars)
- Connectivity issues, frame rate drops, partial loading screen freezing
- Extremely slow combat, a lot of downtime waiting for everything to play out
- Very thin amount of content
- Options and Settings offer little adjustment
- Online community is small, queue times are long as a results
